channel.title: Logseq ‚Äî populated with demo content
channel.description:
BTW: @anderbill and @peterkaminski
Lere's what Logseq looks like after I imported the Peeragogy Handbook contents. ![Screenshot from 2020-11-18 22-28-36|690x388](upload://p1tEOlRWepY9DuxKglI31IDQZUA.png) ![Screenshot from 2020-11-18 22-23-59|690x388](upload://eeouJZMLpFFycW2Qy4N1qfy0XZE.png) ![Screenshot from 2020-11-18 22-23-20|690x388](upload://4b9UfIf59iQ8DkGVuv9DKrKf5GG.png)
This is just one repo: I can imagine for bigger projects (10000's of nodes) we would want to break it across multiple repositories, and probably invest in some more data intensive tooling. I'm not sure where things are "at" with the Free Jerry's Brain effort but this gives a taste of something that seems directly usable now by both "technical" and "nontechnical" users who are willing to spend a few minutes learning. Of course, many technical improvements would be possible later.
If people would like to join in on the Peeragogy site as coauthors, or just for a tour, that could be arranged!
BTW also, Logseq is now directly interoperable with Org Roam in emacs, after a simple bugfix and corresponding change to the config file. https://org-roam.discourse.group/t/logseq-floss-web-outliner-compatible-with-org-roam-now/980
So this means that Emacs-enabled Editors can comfortably do all the things that Logseq makes possible for those webwise inclined.

item.description:
@anderbill ‚Äî I‚Äôd suggest to paste the images you posted here into a new bug report on the Logseq github repository. Any context you could supply would be helpful I‚Äôm sure! However, I‚Äôm not sure what the relevant clues might be. Operating system? Browser difference? Phase of the moon unlikely but‚Ä¶?

Read full topic

item.title: Logseq ‚Äî populated with demo content
item.dc:creator: holtzermann17
item.description:
If there‚Äôs a small amount of sample content from the Brain and your existing downstream formats, it‚Äôd be interested to see what it looks like in this context.

What seems most missing to me personally in the Org (and friends) ecosystem is labeled edges. But I don‚Äôt remember whether The Brain uses them, anyway! And, custom edge-types can be added in Org, they just aren‚Äôt integrated with the Org Roam graphing tools; though, were that done, we‚Äôd have a nice semantic network editor.

BTW should Org Roam itself be interesting, here‚Äôs info on some talks upcoming 28th/29th of November 2020:

Org-roam ‚Äì 10 Nov 20

Org-roam at the EmacsConf 2020: Schedule, Poster, How to Watch, and How to...

Org-roam at the EmacsConf 2020 This year, @noorah and I will be presenting a number of talks on Org-roam: Org-roam: Presentation, Demonstration, and What‚Äôs on the Horizon (@zaeph) Org-mode and Org-Roam for Scholars and Researchers (@noorah) ...

Reading time: 1 mins üïë Likes: 4 ‚ù§

Read full topic

item.title: Logseq ‚Äî populated with demo content
item.dc:creator: peterkaminski
item.description:
holtzermann17:

where things are ‚Äúat‚Äù with the Free Jerry‚Äôs Brain effort but this gives a taste of something that seems directly usable now by both ‚Äútechnical‚Äù and ‚Äúnontechnical‚Äù users who are willing to spend a few minutes

Interesting!

FJB is ‚Äúat‚Äù these tools, each of which is not super fancy:

  • MemeBrane, a simple thought-by-thought web-based navigator, displays the current thought and its linked thoughts;
  • TiddlyBrain, export a subset of thoughts to a TiddlyWiki (which can have TiddlyMap installed, but at least for the current version of TiddlyBrain, TiddlyMap draws an edge per link, so all thoughts ended up with two lines between them, for the link in each direction, and it got messy);
  • SiteBrane, export a subset of thoughts to the Pelican static site generator, to create a static microsite.

Read full topic

Lere‚Äôs what Logseq looks like after I imported the Peeragogy Handbook contents.

This is just one repo: I can imagine for bigger projects (10000‚Äôs of nodes) we would want to break it across multiple repositories, and probably invest in some more data intensive tooling. I‚Äôm not sure where things are ‚Äúat‚Äù with the Free Jerry‚Äôs Brain effort but this gives a taste of something that seems directly usable now by both ‚Äútechnical‚Äù and ‚Äúnontechnical‚Äù users who are willing to spend a few minutes learning. Of course, many technical improvements would be possible later.

If people would like to join in on the Peeragogy site as coauthors, or just for a tour, that could be arranged!

BTW also, Logseq is now directly interoperable with Org Roam in emacs, after a simple bugfix and corresponding change to the config file.

Org-roam ‚Äì 18 Nov 20

Logseq: FLOSS web outliner, compatible with Org Roam now

Logseq is a Roam-like thing in the browser that supports both Markdown and Org Mode. It uses Github as a backing store, which means that you can use it both in the browser, and via Emacs + (Ma)Git. As of this bug fix Logseq seems to have good...

Reading time: 1 mins üïë Likes: 1 ‚ù§

So this means that Emacs-enabled Editors can comfortably do all the things that Logseq makes possible for those webwise inclined.
